column1: Why should you join us?
My name is Mike

column3: we get to peek inside a lot of exciting companies. That’s how I know there’s nowhere else I’d rather be.

column1: Nobody sees the kind of variety that we do. Working here is being immersed in a constant stream of projects across different industries using different technologies. You will learn. A lot. About everything. Our engineers are not just versatile within their own fields firmware engineers work with everything from 8bit micros to embedded Linux to smartphones we also have EEs driving SolidWorks
column3: and FW engineers laying out PCBs. You’ll iterate through many careersworth of projects and solutions faster than you thought possible. And you’ll get better at it each time.

column1: Everyone here loves hardware

column4: discuss our work throughout each day
column5: and build amazing things together. Were constantly in front of clients to extract feedback

column1: Day-to-day

Sleeping soundly because you’re just as proud of your test suite as you are of the code its bulletproofing.
We still operate like a small company within Accenture. As a result

Product Verification and Validation Management - Coordinates the development of design verification and system validation plans from a variety of inputs to identify failure modes while managing risk and relative priority; evaluates analytical and experimental test results following engineering principles to verify that products meet internal technical requirements and to validate that design solutions meet customer needs; produces recommendations with technical documentation to support product decisions.

System Requirements Engineering - Uses appropriate methods and tools to translate stakeholder needs into verifiable requirements to which designs are developed; establishes acceptance criteria for the system of interest through analysis

column4: and resources; creates and maintains information linkages to related artifacts.

column1: Department
2012780 Surgery-Ohns
About the Unit
We are a startup incubated at the TMW Center for Early Learning + Public Health at the University of Chicago
column2: and supported by Schmidt Futures. We’re a rapidly growing team creating technical solutions for pressing challenges in early childhood development. We’re looking for talented individuals who enjoy building and delivering high-quality products. If you’re excited to develop technology for social good
column3: come join us! We’re seeking a highly motivated
column4: hands-on signal processing engineer. You will lead the design and implementation of algorithms on-the-cloud capable of accurately detecting and categorizing adult and child speech. This is a full-time position
column5: but contractor relationships may be considered. We’re based in NYC and Chicago
column6: and remote-friendly. Project Background: Our team’s mission is to give all children an equal opportunity to reach their fullest cognitive potential. Research shows that the most critical window for a child’s brain and language development is from birth to age 3. The most important predictor of a child’s educational success is the quality and quantity of adult-child interactions during these earliest years. Parents need tools that guide them through this formative time period. Our goal is to develop scalable
column7: easy-to-use wearable devices that measure conversational interactions and empower parents. Our product is like a ‘Fitbit’ for early childhood language development - it attaches to a child’s clothing and gathers information about the number of words children are exposed to. It’s connected to a smartphone app that provides feedback to parents and other caregivers on progress and how to improve. The Team: You’ll be joining a talented and enthusiastic team of computer scientists
column11: and design. We’re supported by the Schmidt Futures network
column12: a community of distinguished figures in technology
column14: former CEO of Google and Executive Chairman of Alphabet. The visionary behind this project is Dana Suskind
column16: a pediatric surgeon turned social scientist and author of the 2015 book ‘Thirty Million Words: Building a Child’s Brain’. She co-directs the TMW Center
column17: where she is advancing a novel public health approach that empowers parents to influence their children’s language and cognitive development. Dana’s work has been profiled by numerous media outlets
column21: NPR and Freakonomics among others. Our technical advisory team includes: Pedro Lopes is a technical advisor for wearable device development. He is an Assistant Professor at UChicago
column22: where he leads a research group focused on human computer interaction and wearable computing. Nick Feamster is Neubauer Professor of Computer Science and Director of the Center for Data and Computing at UChicago
column23: and an advisor on security and privacy for IoT devices. Marshini Chetty is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at UChicago. Her focus is advising on human computer interaction
column25: and building technology for empowerment. Ben Zhao is a technical advisor and Neubauer Professor of Computer Science at UChicago. His current research covers a range of topics including adversarial machine learning
column27: and privacy-preserving mobile and wireless systems. Heather Zheng: Heather is the Neubauer Professor of Computer Science at University of Chicago. Heather is a technical advisor on mobile computing and networking. John List: John is a UChicago economist and Chief Economic Advisor at Lyft
column28: known for pioneering field experiments to test economic theory and to provide guidance to policymakers and business leaders. We are looking for an engineer who can lead algorithm development to upgrade the existing device to capture ‘conversational turns’ between parents and children.
